abstract: Apple’s chief said record companies should allow songs to be sold online without anticopying software, in part because the technology does not stop piracy.
snippet: Apple’s chief said record companies should allow songs to be sold online without anticopying software, in part because the technology does not stop piracy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 — Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, jolted the record industry on Tuesday by calling on its largest companies to allow online music sales unfettered by antipiracy software.

headline.main: Jobs Calls for End to Music Copy Protection
headline.print_headline: Apple Chief Urges Shift On Piracy

abstract: Steven P. Jobs says that dropping digital anti-piracy protection would benefit record labels and customers.
snippet: Steven P. Jobs says that dropping digital anti-piracy protection would benefit record labels and customers.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Apple Inc., Steven P. Jobs, is calling on the four largest music companies to license their music for distribution without digital anti-piracy protection, shifting away from a nearly four-year-old philosophy that helped steer the iPod music player to worldwide success.

headline.main: Apple’s Chief Calls for End to Music Copy Protection

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
